q: in his 8-year-old campaign to bring home ancient artifacts spirited out of the country during colonial times. Zahi Hawass wants to see back home. The bust is currently at Berlin's Neues Museum. I am doing something that I believe in and that should have been done a hundred years ago, Zahi Hawass said. "My campaign has united those who have been pillaged against the pillagers. It's the world's greatest campaign of its kind and has inspired many nations to follow suit."

, and he has to prove he is a businessman," Hardy adds. Eric Schmidt 's departure had been a long time coming, says Charles Arthur in The Guardian: After slipups with search, Street View and Android, it's clear that Google needs tighter control at the top- and Eric Schmidt is not the man for the job. What of Google's other co-founder, Sergey Brin ? He is said to be focusing on strategic projects and is particularly interested in social networking. The link in the video above suggests that you go and read the Open Letter from Nokia CEO Stephen Elop and Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer . We've reposted it below for your convenience: Today in London, our two companies announced plans for a broad strategic partnership that combines the respective strengths of our companies and builds a new global mobile ecosystem. The partnership increases our scale, which will result in significant benefits for consumers, developers, mobile operators and businesses around the world. We both are incredibly excited about the journey we are on together. While the specific details of the deal are being worked out, here's a quick summary of what we are working towards: Nokia will adopt Windows Phone as its primary smartphone strategy, innovating on top
